div1.p: To honor the centennial of an old firend of yours, Hamlin Garland, we are preparing to publish a booklet of tributes and reminiscences by his friends and by the Garland scholars.
We feel that this should be our honor and responsibility because Mr. Garland befriended this Library and left us his great collection of manuscripts, letters, and books upon his death in 1940.

From his correspondence, we know that you admired Hamlin Garland's writings, especially upon the American Indian. Will you, therefore, who are also a noted writer in this field, kindly consent to send us a few words of appreciation of this phase of Mr. Garland's work, and whatever else you may care to say? You would thus help us round out our tribute to him. Also, such comment would have pleased Mr. Garland mightily, for he was deeply concerned with the problems of the American Indian and with truly interpreting him to the white man.

We hope that we may hear from your soon, for we have a relatively brief time if we are to issue our tribute during this centennial year. Thank you, sir, for whaver help you can give us in observing the centennial of Hamlin Garland.
